paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses a variant in the KCNH2 gene associated with Short QT Syndrome, detailing its clinical significance, patient information, functional data, and penetrance.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Short QT interval (270–300 ms corrected with Bazett's formula) and family history of sudden cardiac death.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The SQTS was diagnosed many years ago. Two patients from a family were referred for syncope, palpitations, and a strong family history of SCD, which was present in 3 generations.

functional_data.summary: The KCNH2 mutation leads to increased expression of HERG channels, enhancing outward potassium current, shortening action potential duration, and promoting proarrhythmic activity.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in the family.
variants.evidence_level: strong evidence based on family history and functional assays
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the role of KCNH2 in Short QT Syndrome and its implications for familial screening.
key_quotes: The site mutation (p.N588K) in KCNH2 increases the expression of HERG channels and thus enhances outward potassium current, shortens action potential duration, and promotes proarrhythmic activity in short QT‐syndrome–cardiomyocytes.
Three of the family members including our patient presented a short QT interval (270–300 ms corrected with Bazett's formula (QTc) at ECG.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the KCNH2 variant was successfully extracted.
